standards.header: Hospital leaders ensure the conduction of needs assessment related to information management in the hospital.

details.header: The hospital conducts a needs assessment related to information management based on the hospitalâ€™s scope of services, complexity of care and affordable resources including technology.
The needs assessment involves both clinical and managerial staff.
The needs assessment identifies the needs/ requirements of external organizations (e.g., Ministry of Health, accrediting bodies, national research and databases).
Information technology needs are identified and integrated with existing information management processes.
Relevant clinical and managerial staff participate in selecting, integrating, and using information management technology.

standards.header: The hospital maintains an effective information management system to serve its internal and external users and stakeholders.

details.header: The hospital provides adequate resources for an effective information management system.
The hospital describes the categorization of the needed information into manual and computerized.
Data elements are defined and forms are developed for designated staff to enter the necessary data.
Data are collected within predetermined time frames and frequency.
There is a process for secure storage of data and information with easy retrieval.
MOI.2.6 Data and information are accurately and timely disseminated to the targeted internal and external users.
Data and information are disseminated in a format useful for decision making.

standards.header: The hospital develops a process for the information management system modifications, updates, and validation.

details.header: There is process for documentation, approval, and validation of any modification or update related to the information management system.

standards.header: Data collected are transformed into information that is used to support patient care and management decisions.

details.header: Aggregate data and information include information requirements for key functions as specified in this manual (e.g., facility management and safety, infection control, clinical data and information, identified hospital-wide indicators, department-specific indicators, physician- specific information).
Aggregate data and information are used for self-comparison over time and benchmarking against similar hospitals as well as best practices.
The hospital uses the information to make decisions, strategically plan, identify and prioritize quality improvement projects.

standards.header: Hospital leaders as well as users and other staff receive education and training on data management relevant to their roles and responsibilities.

details.header: There is an education/training process for decision makers and other relevant staff on the principles of data management.
The data management education/training is appropriate to the staff roles and responsibilities within the hospital.
The data management education/training includes, but is not limited to, the following:
details: Selection and use of indicators (measures) in assessment and improvement of work processes.
Use of data and information for decision-making.

standards.header: The hospital has a policy and procedures on how confidentiality, security, and integrity of data and information including the medical records are maintained.

details.header: The policy defines data and information confidentiality, security, and integrity.
The policy is in compliance with laws and regulations.
The hospital defines appropriate levels of security and confidentiality for data and information and provides appropriate confidentiality measures accordingly.
Staff access to different categories of information is restricted on a need to know basis.
There is an appropriate mechanism for response to requests for access to information.
Data and information are safeguarded against loss, destruction, tampering, damage, and unauthorized access or use.
There are measures for protecting data and information in the event of a disaster such as flood, fire, loss of power, and abnormal temperature conditions.
Staff responsibilities to maintain confidentiality of data and information are defined (e.g., signing a confidentiality agreement).
Information confidentiality and security incidents are reported and acted upon.

standards.header: The hospital uses a standardized definitions, abbreviations, and symbols.

details.header: The hospital uses standardized and approved definitions.
The hospital implements a list of approved and prohibited abbreviations and symbols.
The lists are consistent with national standards and professional organizations concerned with patient safety.
The lists are developed and approved by the medical staff and other relevant structures (e.g., medical records review committee, pharmacy and therapeutics committee).
The lists are revised periodically (e.g., annually).

standards.header: The hospital has a policy on the retention of data and information.

details.header: There is a policy on the retention of data and information that is consistent with relevant laws and regulations.
The policy defines the length of time required to retain the data and information.
The policy addresses how confidentiality, integrity, and security of the data and information will be maintained during retention.

standards.header: The hospital maintains sufficient provisions that ensure the operation of the information system during scheduled or unscheduled (unexpected) downtime.

details.header: There are procedures and forms to be used during scheduled or unscheduled (unexpected) downtime.
End-users are trained on procedures to follow during interruptions of the information system.
Patient information are documented and reported during the downtime (e.g., reporting laboratory results).
The integrity of the system and data entry is verified after the downtime.
There is review of the downtime assessment report.
The downtime system is regularly tested for effectiveness.

standards.header: The hospital implements a process for data backup.

details.header: The hospital has a process in place for regular information system data backup and retrieval.

standards.header: The hospital uses and contributes to comparative reference databases in accordance with national guidelines.

details.header: The hospital contributes to external databases in accordance with national laws and regulations.
The hospital uses external reference databases for comparative purposes to identify areas in which performance deviates from expected patterns.

standards.header: There is a process for the clinical and administrative staff to obtain information that support safe patient care.

details.header: Information resources are available to address clinical and administrative staff needs and support them to maintain and improve their competencies.

Information resources support patient care, patient safety, patient education, performance improvement, educational functions for hospital and medical staff, research, and other appropriate functions.
Information resources are accessible when needed (e.g., books and journals).
